awd_titl_txt: Polymer Precursors for Interfaces, Binders and Adhesives for Ceramic Solid-State Battery Components
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The electrification of society mandates the development of safer, high energy density methods of storing chemical energy. One clear objective is the development of all-solid state batteries (ASBs), especially those relying on ceramic electrolytes, as they offer the best potential to realize safe, high energy density storage potentially eliminating many of the short-comings of current state-of-the-art battery systems used world-wide. Because ceramic electrolytes are typically sintered at temperatures that exceed those needed to process anode and cathode materials; the assembly of ASBs requires an approach that leads to well-defined interfaces between components and good mating of surfaces coincident with effective ion transport across the interface without also compromising the individual components. Carefully designed polymers that act as adhesives have been developed that offer all of the requisite properties to serve this purpose. Of further importance, on heating to temperatures well below those used to form the cathode, electrolyte and some anode materials, they form glassy or ceramic interfaces that function as anticipated. Indeed, their performance exceeds similar interfaces produced using high vacuum sputtering methods sometimes by orders of magnitude. The reasons for this behavior are not known and yet offer exceptional potential to realize superior ASBs using lower cost processing methods providing that the basic science behind their behavior can be fully explored. This then is the basis for the project described here. Over the course of the project, up to three graduate students and several undergraduate students will be engaged in research; diversity is a priority in the selection of students. Engagement with local Detroit and Yspilanti schools is an ongoing priority to attract underserved populations to science and engineering careers. Research results will be disseminated via tradi-tional scientific journals, international meetings especially with presentations by students, via workshops (where appropriate) and through the creation of new training videos. If successful, it is anticipated that the approach and methods under development could (i) reduce reliance on scarce elements, and (ii) significantly impact how solid-state batteries are assembled given its potential to simplify the assembly process while also increasing energy densities and greatly improving battery safety compared with state-of-the-art batteries currently used commercially. 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Polymer derived ceramics (PDCs), precursors to advanced ceramics, is an area first explored more than 40 years ago. The principles concerning their design, processing and characterization for properties optimization were developed by this group originally for structural ceramics, e.g. SiC and YAG ceramic fibers for ceramic/ceramic composites. More recently these principles were applied to designing and optimizing processing of oxide superconducting fibers. This project extends these principles to develop, optimize and especially establish structure-processing-properties relationships to Li+, Na+ and possibly Mg2+ containing glasses/ceramics. Initial studies show that polymers containing Li, P, O, N, H and Li (LiPON precursors) can be formulated and used as coatings and adhesives for multiple thin film (under 50 um) ceramic electrolyte, cathode and anode components; i.e. LATSP, LLZO, LiA-lOx, LTO, etc. The resulting materials provide Li+ conductivities up to 103x superior to gas phase deposited LiPON. This project focuses on developing a detailed understanding of the stepwise molecular and phase evolution of a set of LiPON-like precursors in an effort to clarify the mechanism(s) whereby the molecular to ceramic transformations enable  the unexpected, exceptional ion conducting behavior. One long term goal is to use the anticipated outcomes of these studies to improve the utility of LiAlOx electrolytes to the point where the complex processing needed to produce high quality, thin LATSP and/or LLZO films is no longer a necessary part of the assembly of ASBs thereby resulting in lower cost ASBs.

Polymer Precursors for Interfaces, Binders and Adhesives for Ceramic Solid-State Battery Components


PI: Richard  M. Laine
Awardee: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor  
Award Number: 1926199
Award Ends:07/31/2022
Program Officer Name: Birgit Schwenzer  
Program Officer Email Address: bschwenz@nsf.gov
Program Officer Phone Number: (703)292-4771

 

The design and assembly of components for all solid-state Li+ batteries, ASSBs, encompasses multiple areas of research and is of intense current interest because of the ongoing electrification of society with enormous emphasis on electric vehicles. Work towards ASSBs is also motivated by safety concerns given recent catastrophic failures of liquid electrolyte batteries.

One solution to the latter problem is to replace liquid electrolytes with ceramic electrolytes of equivalent performance; oft cited examples are LATP [Li1.3Al0.3Ti1.7(PO4)3] and c-LLZO (cubic Li7La3Zr2O12) offering Li+ conductivities of 0.1-4 mS/cm depending on the format tested. Unfortunately, both materials fail in ASSB applications. In LATSP, Ti4+ is irreversibly reduced during cycling; whereas, in c-LLZO, Li dendrites can grow along grain boundaries short circuiting ASSBs. Solutions to these problems use thin film amorphous Li+ conducting electrolytes typified by the LiPON family of materials. Unfortunately, LiPON Li+ conductivities are 0.01-0.001 mS/cm mandating its use as thin films typically 50-100 nm thick. Furthermore, to date such films have only been applied using vacuum deposition methods including magnetron sputtering, CVD and ALD; all difficult/costly to scale to commercial levels. One must consider the fact that batteries designed for general applications in society must be considered commodity products and thus cost of manufacture must be quite low to be considered commercially viable.

At the University of Michigan (UM) we have identified an alternate, low-temperature route to LiPON thin films using solution coatable polymer precursors (see Equation 1). We have developed polymer precursors to LiPON-like materials and tested their utility on dense, thin film (20-50 nm) a-Al2O3, LiAlO2, LATSP substrates chosen because they offer a range of Li+ conductivities from 0 to 4 mS/cm. The starting chemicals used in their preparation meet the commodity criterion just noted. The resulting polymers offer potential in their own right as electrolytes.

The precursors developed here application the above substrates and heated to just 400 ?C/N2, give Li+ conductivities 1-2 orders of magnitude superior to traditionally applied LiPON. Additionally, when used just as polymer electrolytes alone or better as solid solutions in polyethylene oxide (PEO), they offer room temperature Li+ conductivities of >1 mS/cm2 where most PEO based systems must be used at 65 ?C where PEO melts.

A further discovery in this work was that we could make battery components from the agricultural waste, rice hull ash (see Scheme 1) including both Li+ conducting polymers w/wo PEO and also silicon carbide (SiC) and silicon oxynitride (Si2N2O) both of which can be used as anode materials in half cells against Li metal offering capacities approaching 1000 mAh/g or just less than 3x the commercially used graphite materials (See Figures 1 and 2).  Note given that the starting materials are an agricultural waste these materials are carbon neutral suggesting sustainable, green and low cost routes to high energy solid state batteries.

 

Intellectual Merits

The design and optimization of polymer precursors to glasses/ceramcs and methods of processing them into a wide variety of thin films, binders, adhesives and ion conducting fillers offers a low energy/low cost alternative to gas phase processing of LiPON and LiPON-like materials. Preliminary data demonstrate that this approach provides interface materials that exhibit ion conducting properties one to two orders of magnitude superior to similar materials deposited by gas phase methods. Furthermore, in related engineering studies we find that such precursors can provide adhesives that can be used with ceramic thin film electrolytes and cathode materials that on heating to just 400 ?C form glass/ceramic interfaces. Finally, in these same engineering studies we find that these coatings offer the potential to realize Li-S theoretical energy densities of exceptional importance to realizing some of the best ASBs theoretically possible.

Broader Impacts

The transformation of worldwide society from combustion energy to renewable energy sources relies extensively on the ability to store, transport and expend energy where needed for mobility of all kinds. Thus, any efforts to minimize the cost of energy transport, e.g. as batteries, will greatly impact society. Initial work presented here suggests a new approach to assembling ASSBs that should be easier, offer more flexibility in battery design, and appears to provide a lower cost mechanism for assembly. As such, there appears to be an opportunity for immense impact to society if our proposed work holds true in extending the preliminary work presented here.
